conversation.message:
Dear Parent_E,

Thank you for your application this round and for confirming again that Nursery_E remains your first choice and that you can complete paperwork/deposit within 24 hours.

At this time, we are not able to offer you the place, as we must continue to hold our remaining capacity in line with our admissions priority order for higher-priority families (Parent_A through Parent_D).

On when to check back / what trigger would release the place: the trigger is that we receive no active application/confirmation from any higher-priority family (Parent_A–Parent_D) and we are able to conclude that none will be taking the place at that point. Because that depends on whether those families engage in a given round, we cannot provide a fixed deadline within the round. The earliest practical point to check back is next round.

We have kept your details on file (immediate start flexibility and 24-hour completion). If the place becomes available with no higher-priority family requiring an offer first, we will be able to move quickly.

Sincerely,
Nursery_E Admissions

Given the market preferences, Parent_A ranks Nursery_E last and is unlikely to apply; Parents B–D also rank Nursery_E 4th/5th, so the chance of receiving them is low but still possible if they are rejected elsewhere. Accepting Parent_E now would foreclose the opportunity to match with any higher-priority parent should they approach later. Therefore we reject again while giving a clear trigger/check-back guidance.

Our quota is 1 and remains unfilled, but in principle we should only accept Parent_E if it is clear no higher-priority parents (Parent_A–Parent_D) will apply/accept us. Given the market preferences: Parent_A ranks Nursery_E last; Parent_B ranks Nursery_E 4th; Parent_C ranks Nursery_E last; Parent_D ranks Nursery_E last. So only Parent_B has any realistic chance to come to us, but even Parent_B prefers A and C and B over E. With only one round left (round 29 now, round 30 final), the probability of getting a higher-priority parent is low, but not zero. However, if we reject again and no higher-priority parent comes by round 30, we risk ending unmatched, which is worse than matching with Parent_E (who is still on our acceptable list). Since our objective is to match with as high as possible within quota, and the time horizon is almost over, the optimal move is to accept Parent_E now to secure a match rather than gamble on a very unlikely higher-priority late application.
